choices.text: Stimulation of continuation of reduction division of oocytes
FSH increases steroid synthesis in granulosa cells
Activin causes FSH to act on granulosa cells

questions.text: Which of the below is seen in the ovulatory phase?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During oogenesis the primary oocyte is arrested in prophase of meiosis 1. Just before ovulation, the LH surge initiates the continuation of meiosis, forming a secondary oocyte and 1st polar body.
  • The LH surge initiates the resumption of meiosis in the oocyte (meiosis is not completed until after the sperm has entered and the second polar body is released.

Explanation of other options:

  • Inhibin A is increased in ovulatory phase(Option B): Levels of inhibin A are increased and reach peak in mid luteal phase, not in ovulatory phase.
  • FSH increases steroid synthesis in granulosa cells(Option C):FSH acts on the granulosa cells to produce estrogen mainly in the follicular phase and not in ovulatory phase.
  • Activin causes FSH to act on the granulosa cells(Option D):As discussed, activin does augment the action of FSH on granulosa cells but during early follicular phase and not during ovulatory phase.
  • In the granulosa of the early follicular phase, activin augments FSH activities: FSH receptor expression, aromatization, inhibin/ activin production, and LH receptor expression.
  • In the theca, activin suppresses androgen production, allowing the emergence of an estrogen microenvironment.

questions.text: Ferning of cervical mucus depends on:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Estrogen is responsible for the secretion of cervical mucus and progesterone is responsible for making it thick and viscid. Under the influence of estrogen cervical mucus is copious, watery elastic (can be stretched) and it shows a characteristic fern pattern.(Option B,C and D ruled out)
  • Under the influence of progesterone cervical mucus is thick, loses its stretchability and does not show a fern like pattern.

questions.text: In the perspective of the busy life schedule in the modern society, the accepted minimum period of sexual cohabitation resulting in no offspring for a couple to be declared infertile is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • If a couple fails to achieve pregnancy after one year of "unprotected" and regular intercourse, it is an indication to investigate the couple for infertility.(Option B,C and D ruled out)

Infertility:

  • Primary :When no previous pregnancies have occurred.
  • Secondary :When a prior pregnancy although not necessary a live birth, has occurred

questions.text: What is the first-line investigation for evaluating male factor infertility?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Semen analysis is the basic and initial test for assessing male fertility.(Option A,C and D ruled out)
  • It evaluates:
    • Sperm count
    • Motility
    • Morphology
    • Volume and liquefaction
  • It is non-invasive, cost-effective, and provides direct information about spermatogenesis and ejaculatory function.

Explanation for answer:

Differential Diagnosis of Infertility

questions.text: All are semen analysis criteria according to WHO 2020 except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Semen analysis is the basic and initial test for assessing male fertility.
  • It evaluates:
    • Sperm count
    • Motility
    • Morphology
    • Volume and liquefaction
  • It is non-invasive, cost-effective, and provides direct information about spermatogenesis and ejaculatory function.

Semen Analysis (WHO-2020)(Option A,B and D ruled out)

questions.text: The risk of Asherman syndrome is the highest if Dilatation and Curettage (D and C) is done for the following condition:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Asherman Syndrome is the formation of intrauterine adhesions (scar tissue) often resulting from trauma to the endometrial lining. The most common cause is Dilatation and Curettage (D&C), especially when performed in a setting where the endometrium is more vulnerable to damage like in Postpartum hemorrhage.(Option C ruled out)
  • D&C in Missed abortion and MTP poses risk of adhesions but less than PPH.(Option A and C ruled out)

questions.text: What is the cause for luteal phase defect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Luteal Phase Defect:During normal luteal phase, when there is adequate progesterone secretion by the corpus luteum, adequate development of secretory endometrium occurs for blastocyst implantation. Luteal phase defect refers to a condition when production of progesterone is suboptimal by corpus luteum.(Option B,C and D ruled out)
  • Inadequate progesterone secretion could be due to:
    • Inadequate follicular development
    • Inadequate FSH or LH secretion
    • Hyperprolactinemia

questions.text: Patient Smita is a case of infertility. What is the right time in her menstrual cycle to do an endometrial biopsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Luteal phase defects can be diagnosed by endometrial biopsy (which shows a lag of 2 - 3 days) between the calendar and histological dating of specimens.
    Note: For the diagnosis of luteal phase defect, an endometrial biopsy is done between day 24-26 of the menstrual cycle or 2 to 4 days before anticipated menstruation.(Option A,B and D ruled out)
  • Endometrial biopsy is contraindicated in suspected malignancy/sepsis.
  • 1st sign of ovulation on endometrial biopsy is parabasal vacuolation.
  • Also know:
  • Endometrial biopsy for diagnosis of TB should be done in the late premenstrual phase Q as tubercles are present in the superficial layer and shed during menstruation. The tissue obtained is subjected to polymerase chain reaction tests instead of culture.

questions.text: Drugs used for ovulation induction are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ovulation induction is primarily used in women with anovulation or oligo-ovulation, particularly in PCOS and other causes of infertility. Several pharmacologic agents are used to stimulate ovulation.
  • Danazol is a synthetic androgen.It works by inhibiting the mid-cycle LH surge.
  • It suppresses ovulation and is used to treat endometriosis, not to induce ovulation.Thus, it is contraindicated in women who desire fertility.

Most commonly used drugs for ovulation induction:(Option B,C and D ruled out)

  1. Clomiphene citrate (CC)
  2. Letrozole
  3. Gonadotropins

Clomiphene Citrate(Option B ruled out):Enclomiphene is a more potent isomer responsible for its ovulation-inducing action.

  • Dose = 50-250 mg. However, the US FDA-approved maximum dose for clomiphene citrate is 100 mg
  • Clomiphene blocks "Estrogen" receptors → increase FSH from pituitary → growth of follicles
  • Thus it can be used only in patients with intact hypothalamic -pituitary ovarian axis
  • With clomiphene success rate for ovulation is 80% and success rate for pregnancy is 40%

Letrozole(Option D ruled out): It is an aromatase inhibitor which blocks the conversion of testosterone to estrogen, leading to increased FSH from pituitary.

Gonadotropins(Option C ruled out): HMG (Human Menopausal Gonadotropin obtained from the urine of the menopausal women) and recombinant FSH.

  • Menopausal women have high FSH and LH levels in their blood and urine, and HMG is extracted from urine of menopausal females.
  • Follicular study is done along with ovulation induction to monitor the growth of follicles and when the dominant follicle is 18-20 mm, ovulation trigger is given to rupture the follicle
  • For ovulation trigger, M/C drug used is hCG (derived from the urine of pregnant women or by recombinant technology)
  • Ovulation occurs 36 hours after injecting hCG.

questions.text: A patient treated for infertility with clomiphene citrate presents with sudden onset of abdominal pain and distension with ascites, the probable cause is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient was treated with clomiphene citrate, a drug commonly used for ovulation induction. When a patient on such therapy presents with sudden abdominal pain, distension, and ascites, the most probable diagnosis is Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome.

Extra Edge: Classification and staging of OHSS -

Mild OHSS: enlarged ovaries (5-10 cms)

Moderate OHSS: Ovaries > 10 cms, abdominal distension, nausea, vomiting diarrhea

Severe OHSS: Ovaries > 12 cms, ascites, hydrothorax & after atoms in blood viscosity.

Life threatening OHSS:

  • Valuably enlarged ovaries
  • WBC> 25,000
  • Hematocrit > 55%
  • Creature level > 1.6 mph
  • Oliguria
  • Renal failure
  • Tense ascites
  • Thromboembolic phenomenon
  • ARDS

Management: OHSS is managed conservatively.

  • Admit the patient (if the patient's hematocrit is > 0.44, or has abnormal renal or liver function).
  • 1st line therapy - correction of hypovolemia.
  • Prophylactic heparin to reduce the risk of thromboembolic complications.
  • When the abdomen is tense and ascites are evident both clinically and on ultrasound, drainage of ascites should be done (paracentesis).

Surgical intervention has no role in OHSS.

Explanation of other options:

  • Uterine rupture(Option A):Typically occurs in late pregnancy or labor, especially in women with previous uterine surgery (e.g., cesarean section).Presents with sudden severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and loss of fetal station.Not associated with clomiphene use or infertility treatment.
  • Ectopic pregnancy rupture(Option B): It Can cause sudden abdominal pain, hypotension, and signs of shock, but usually after a missed period with positive pregnancy test.There is no mention of amenorrhea or pregnancy in the question.Also, ascites due to ectopic rupture would be hemoperitoneum, not clear fluid.
  • Multifetal pregnancy(Option C): It is Associated with ovulation induction (especially with clomiphene or gonadotropins).May cause gradual abdominal distension, but not sudden pain, ascites, or signs of third spacing.Presents later in gestation, not in early infertility treatment phase.

questions.text: Fallopian tube dysmotility is seen:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), also known as immotile ciliary syndrome orKartagener syndrome (KS), is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder in which there is a congenital absence of dynein arms (a protein structure associated with motility) in all body cilia.
  • It can lead to male factor infertility due to diminished sperm motility in males. As far as female infertility is concerned.
  • The classic Kartagener Syndrome triad includes:
    1. Bronchiectasis - chronic dilation and inflammation of the bronchi, leading to recurrent respiratory infections.
    2. Chronic sinusitis - persistent inflammation and infection of the paranasal sinuses.
    3. Situs inversus - reversal of the normal position of internal organs (e.g., heart on the right side).

Explanation of other options:

  • Noonan Syndrome(Option A):Genetic disorder with features like short stature, webbed neck, and cardiac anomalies (e.g., pulmonary stenosis).No known association with ciliary dysfunction or fallopian tube dysmotility.
  • Turner Syndrome (45,X)(Option B): It Causes streak ovaries, primary amenorrhea, and infertility due to gonadal dysgenesis.The issue is hormonal and structural ovarian failure, not fallopian tube motility.
  • Marfan Syndrome(Option D):A connective tissue disorder due to fibrillin-1 mutation.Involves skeletal, ocular, and cardiovascular systems (e.g., aortic aneurysm, lens dislocation).No involvement of ciliary function or fallopian tube motility.

questions.text: Best Investigation to assess tubal patency:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The gold standard / best investigation to assess tubal patency is laparoscopic chromopertubation.
  • Laparoscopy enables one to look at the external condition of the uterus, tubes and pelvis and at the same time the patency of tubes can be seen. Methylene blue/indigo carmine dye is injected through a cannula attached to the cervix to visualize the free spill or absence of spill. It can also demonstrate peritubal adhesions and unsuspected endometriosis.
  • The greatest advantage of laparoscopy is therapeutic procedure can be performed if adhesions or fimbrial block is recognized in one sitting.
  • Also known: Other questions frequently asked on tubal patency tests.
  • Time for performing tubal patency tests: Day 7 - Day 10 of cycle
  • No anesthesia is required for tube testing
  • First test to assess tubal patency is HCG
    • HSG is not the best test because it cannot differentiate between cornual spasm and cornual blockage.
    • Obsolete method of testing tubal patency - Rubins test / CO2Insufflation test(in preovulatory phase)
  • The best test as discussed is laparoscopic chromopertubation.
  • Other tests are:
    • Sonosalpingography i
    • Falloscopy
    • Salpingoscopy

questions.text: Lady with infertility with bilateral tubal block at cornual end, best method of management is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a woman with infertility and bilateral cornual (proximal) tubal block seen on HSG, the first step is not immediate surgery but to confirm the diagnosis. The cornual block may sometimes be spurious, caused by tubal spasm or mucus plugs.(Option B,C and D ruled out)
  • Hence, the best initial approach is Laparoscopy to confirm the tubal obstruction and rule out other pelvic pathology.Hysteroscopy to visualize the uterine end of the tubes and attempt tubal cannulation.
  • This combined approach:
    • Confirms whether the occlusion is real.
    • Allows non-invasive cannulation, which may restore tubal patency.
    • Avoids major surgery or IVF if successful.

Tubal block management:

  • Unilateral proximal tubal block:
    • Hysteroscopic cannulation or microsurgical cornual anastomosis (especially if peritoneal adhesions are present).
  • Distal tubal block:
    • IVF is the best option. Surgical alternatives include fimbrioplasty or neosalpingostomy.
  • Distal tubal block with hydrosalpinx:
    • Laparoscopic salpingectomy followed by IVF.
  • Bipolar (proximal + distal) tubal block:
    • Best managed with IVF directly.

questions.text: First test to assess tubal patency is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • First test to assess tubal patency - HSG:X-ray with contrast to visualize uterine cavity + tubal Spills. It is First-line, outpatient, simple, cost-effective.
    • HSG is not the best test because it cannot differentiate between Cornual spasm and Cornual blockade.
    • Obsolete test for tubal patency - Rubin's test/CO2insufflation test
    • Best test - Laparoscopic Chromopertubation
  • Laparoscopy with chromopertubation is the Gold standard for tubal patency + pelvic pathology (adhesions, endometriosis).But it's invasive, so not the first.Falloscopy is rarely done.(Option B,C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Post coital test detects all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Post coital test (Sims or Huhner's test)is a test for evaluation of the potential role of Cervical factor in infertility. It is designed to assess:
    • The quality of cervical mucus.(Option A ruled out)
    • Presence and number of motile sperms in the female reproductive tract after coitus.(Option D ruled out)
    • Interaction between cervical mucus and sperms.
    • It gives an approximate idea of sperm count: (normally 10 -50 motile sperms are seen per high power field in cervical mucus, if count is < 10 sperms / HPF it indicates the need for complete semen analysis).(Option C ruled out)
  • Post coital test gives a very rough idea about sperm count, motility and morphology.
  • As far as fallopian tube block is concerned postcoital test has no relation whatsoever with it and we have to select
  • Time of test:
    • It should be performed 1 or 2 days before the anticipated time of ovulation, when maximum estrogen secretion is present.
    • For patients with irregular cycles, a patient's urinary LH surge may be helpful in scheduling the test.
  • Prerequisites for the test: Abstinence of 2 days.
    • Intercourse is to be performed 2-12 hours before the test.
    • No use of lubricant.

questions.text: Treatment for Cervical infertility can be all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cervical factor infertility can be due to abnormal or deficient mucus

  • Infection
  • Prior cervical surgery
  • Use of antiestrogens (e.g. clomiphene citrate) for ovulation induction (so clomiphene is a cause of cervical factor infertility rather than management)
  • Sperm antibodies

The treatment of cervical factor thus depends on the cause:

  • If it is due to chronic cervicitis/infection - Treatment of infection by antibiotics is the cure.
  • If it is due to decreased mucus volume - Treatment includes short term supplementation with exogenous estrogen like ethinyl estradiol and use of mucolytic expectorant like guaifenesin. However, their value has not been confirmed.
  • If it is due to antisperm antibodies. Treatment options include:
    • Use of condom or diaphragm as a barrier method for 3 months. During this period, the antibodies will disappear and conception may occur then.(Option A ruled out)
    • Corticosteroids given to female partners can also help in getting rid of these antibodies
  • Intrauterine insemination at the time of ovulation (most acceptable method for cervical factor infertility) or GIFT (Gamete intrafallopian transfer) are very useful techniques in such cases.
  • IUI is the best method for treating cervical factor infertility and unexplained infertility. So many clinicians forgo cervical mucus testing and proceed directly to IUI treatment in absence of tubal disease.(Option B and C ruled out)

questions.text: Which is an essential criteria according to WHO for normal semen analysis:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) defines normal semen parameters based on large population-based studies of fertile men.

Semen analysis - WHO(Option A ,C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Aspermia is the term used to describe:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Aspermia refers to failure of formation or emission of semen.
  • The absence of spermatozoa in semen is known as Azoospermia.

Semen Analysis Terminology(Option B,C and D ruled out)

questions.text: A male with a history of recurrent respiratory infections since childhood presents for evaluation of infertility. Which of the following is most likely true about his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This clinical presentation is classic for Kartagener syndrome, a subtype of Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD). The hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis is intact and hence FSH and LH levels are normal.(Option A,C and D ruled out)It is an Autosomal recessive disease.
  • Classic triad:
    • Bronchiectasis
    • Recurrent sinusitis
    • Situs inversus
  • Due to dynein arm defect → affects ciliary motility → leads to impaired mucociliary clearance and infertility

questions.text: In azoospermia, the diagnostic test which can distinguish between testicular failure and obstruction of Vas deferens is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a male with azoospermia (absence of sperm in ejaculate), the two main categories of causes are:
    1. Obstructive azoospermia: Normal spermatogenesis but blockage in the reproductive tract (e.g., vas deferens obstruction).
    2. Non-obstructive azoospermia (Testicular failure): Impaired or absent spermatogenesis due to intrinsic testicular dysfunction.
  • High FSH → suggests testicular failure (non-obstructive azoospermia)
  • Normal FSH → suggests obstructive azoospermia (vas deferens or epididymal block)
  • Non-invasive, widely used screening method(Option D ruled out)
  • Recommended as first diagnostic step
  • Testosterone usually remains normal in both conditions (Leydig cells unaffected in obstruction and sometimes in testicular failure) and Karyotyping is useful in suspected genetic causes (Klinefelter, Yq deletion),(Option B and C ruled out)

questions.text: A couple complains of primary infertility in spite of staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse, all tests in the wife are normal. Semen analysis shows a volume of 0.8 ml/sperm count is 0, fructose is absent. What is done next?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Absent fructose in semen indicates either there is congenital absence of seminal vesicles or there is obstruction in the ejaculatory duct system.
  • The best way to detect obstruction is to perform a transrectal ultrasound.
  • Local palpation of vas is a simple bedside step (absence of vas in CBAVD), also testicular FNAC is done to differentiate obstructive vs non-obstructive azoospermia but since obstruction needs confirmation, imaging is preferred after semen findings.(Option A,C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Intrauterine insemination is done for all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Indication

  • Intrauterine insemination is done in males with:
    • Severe hypospadias
    • Retrograde ejaculation (Immediate postcoital urine is taken and sperms are extracted from it.)
    • Neurogenic impotence
    • Sexual dysfunction
    • Oligospermia(Option B ruled out)
    • Asthenospermia
    • Low ejaculate volume
  • In female infertility IUI is useful in:
    • Cervical infertility-Antisperm antibodies are present in cervix(Option A ruled out)
    • Vaginismus (involuntary contraction of perineal muscles during intercourse)
    • Unexplained infertility.(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Methods for sperm retrieval in case of azoospermia are all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Methods of Sperm Retrieval in Case of Azoospermia(Option A,B and C ruled out)
    • Microsurgical Epididymal Sperm aspiration : MESA-Surgical method to aspirate sperm from epididymis.
    • Percutaneous Epididymal Sperm aspiration : PESA-Method of sperm retrieval from epididymis
    • Testicular sperm extraction : TESE-Retrieval directly from testicular tissue.
    • Percutaneous Testicular sperm fine needle aspiration : TESA(also called Fine Needle Aspiration FNA).
  • The choice of the method depends on:
    • The underlying diagnosis,
    • Whether goal of the procedure is diagnostic or therapeutic
    • Whether isolated sperm will be used immediately or cryopreserved.
  • GIFT is gamete intrafallopian transfer for artificial reproductive technique.

questions.text: Aspiration of sperms from testes is done in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • TESA (Testicular Sperm Aspiration),Involves inserting a needle directly into the testis to aspirate seminiferous tubules containing sperm.
  • Used in:
    • Non-obstructive azoospermia
    • Severe oligospermia
  • Sperms obtained are used for ICSI (Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection).
  • Sperm retrieval or recovery can be done by:(Option B,C and D ruled out)
    • Microsurgical epididymal sperm aspiration : MESA
    • Percutaneous epididymal sperm aspiration : PESA
    • Testicular sperm extraction : TESE
    • Percutaneous testicular sperm fine needle aspiration : TESA
  • The choice of the method depends on:
    • The underlying diagnosis,
    • Whether goal of the procedure is diagnostic or therapeutic
    • Whether isolated sperm will be used immediately or cryopreserved.

questions.text: Which is not an assisted reproduction technique:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All methods of ART, by definition, involve interventions to retrieve oocytes. These techniques include IVF, ICSI, GIFT, ZIFT, Cryopreserved embryo transfers, and the use of donor oocytes.
  • Artificial insemination involves introducing sperm directly into the female reproductive tract (e.g., intrauterine insemination). No manipulation of eggs or fertilization outside the body. Hence Not considered ART by strict definition (although it is a fertility treatment).

Explanation of other options:

  • GIFT: Gamete Intra-Fallopian Transfer(Option A):Oocytes and sperm are placed together in the fallopian tube via laparoscopy.Fertilization occurs in vivo but both gametes are handled outside the body, thus classified as ART.
  • ZIFT : Zygote Intrafallopian Transfer(Option B):Oocyte is fertilized in vitro, and the zygote is placed into the fallopian tube.Fertilization is outside the body, so it is ART.
  • IVF and ET: In Vitro Fertilization and Embryo Transfer(Option C):Fertilization and early embryonic development occur entirely outside the body, and the embryo is transferred to the uterus.Classical ART technique.

questions.text: Success rate of IVF per cycle is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The live birth rate per IVF cycle varies with age, but on average:
    • Around 30% per cycle in women <35 years.(Option A,B and C ruled out)
    • Declines with increasing age.
  • Excess embryos not used for transfer can be cryopreserved for an unlimited period, with a survival rate of 75%.

questions.text: In semen banks, semen is preserved at low temperature using:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cryopreservation of semen:

  • Involves cooling of embryos in the pronuclear stage or early cleavage stage to very low temperature in the presence of cryoprotectants such as:
    • I2- Propanediol (Iodine)
    • Glycerol
    • dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO) with sucrose.
  • They are then stored in liquid nitrogen till required.(Option A,B and D ruled out)
  • Over half the embryos survive the thawing process.
  • Oocyte preservation has not been successful.
  • No adverse effects have been seen in babies born by this technique.

questions.text: Tests for ovarian reserve are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ovarian reserve tests are to assess the quantity as well as the quality of primordial follicles present in the women's ovary. These tests are done to determine how the ovaries will respond to therapy (ovulation induction) in other words it is the assessment of the reproductive potential of the woman.

The Tests Done Are:

  1. Estimation of basal level of serum FSH on D3 and again on D10 following clomiphene citrate challenge test (CCCT): 100 mg orally each day from D5-D9: values >10 IU/L (more than 2SD) indicates poor ovarian reserve.(Option C ruled out)
  2. Basal (D3) serum estradiol level > 70-80 pg/mL, poor ovarian reserve.(Option D ruled out)
  3. Serum inhibin B (D5): Reduced inhibin B levels (less than 40 pg/mL) are observed in women with advanced age.
  4. Serum antimüllerian Hormone (AMH): Levels of AMH (1ng/mL) declines with age and with poor ovarian reserve. Levels of AMH can be measured any time in the menstrual cycle.(Option A ruled out)

choices.text: Rise in basal body temperature in the second half of cycle

questions.text: Ovulation can be diagnosed by all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Serum progesterone is measured on D 22 to show the rise and not on D14.
  • Ovulation diagnosis can be confirmed by evaluating physiological, hormonal, and histological changes associated with the luteal phase (post-ovulation phase).Ovulation typically occurs around day 14 in a 28-day cycle.Progesterone rises after ovulation, secreted by the corpus luteum.

Explanation of other options:

  • Rise in basal body temperature (BBT)(Option B):Progesterone has a thermogenic effect, causing BBT to rise by ~0.5°C after ovulation.BBT charting over a few cycles can suggest whether ovulation is occurring.Rise in BBT confirms luteal phase, hence ovulation.
  • Study of cervical mucus(Option C):Under the influence of estrogen, cervical mucus becomes clear, stretchy, and spinnbarkeit positive around ovulation.Changes in mucus quality help predict imminent ovulation.
  • Endometrial histology(Option D):Invasive but definitive.If a biopsy is taken in the late luteal phase, a secretory endometrium confirms ovulation has occurred.Outdated, but classically used in infertility workup.

questions.text: Indications of intrauterine insemination (IUI) are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Indication

  • Intrauterine insemination is done in males with:
    • Severe hypospadias
    • Retrograde ejaculation (Immediate postcoital urine is taken and sperms are extracted from it.)
    • Neurogenic impotence
    • Sexual dysfunction
    • Oligospermia(Option C ruled out)
    • Asthenospermia
    • Low ejaculate volume
  • In female infertility IUI is useful in:
    • Cervical infertility-Antisperm antibodies are present in cervix(Option A ruled out)
    • Vaginismus (involuntary contraction of perineal muscles during intercourse)
    • Unexplained infertility.(Option B ruled out)

choices.text: Antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucus

questions.text: Artificial insemination with husband's semen is indicated in all the following situations, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Azoospermia means complete absence of sperm in the semen.If there are no sperm, insemination using the husband's semen is futile.Such cases require:
    • Use of donor sperm (AID - Artificial Insemination by Donor)
    • Surgical sperm retrieval followed by IVF/ICSI, if sperm is present in the testes.
  • IUI may be either artificial insemination of husband's semen called homologousinsemination or artificial insemination of donor semen called Heterologous insemination. Husband's semen is commonly used. The purpose of IUI is to bypass the endocervical canal which is abnormal and to place increased concentration of motile sperm as close to the fallopian tubes.
  • AIH can be used in cases of oligospermia (if the sperm count is low but adequate), impotency (when the husband cannot deposit semen naturally), and antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucus (since AIH bypasses the cervix).(Option A,B and C ruled out)

questions.text: The major contribution to the human seminal fluid is from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Seminal fluid (semen) is composed of spermatozoa and secretions from several accessory sex glands. While sperm is produced by the testes, the bulk of the fluid volume in semen comes from seminal vesicles(60%) and prostate(90%).
  • The seminal vesicle contributes 60% and the prostate about 30% of the seminal fluid.

Explanation of other options:

  • Testes(Option A):Testes produce spermatozoa, but contribute very little to seminal volume.Sperm forms only 2-5% of the semen.Not a major contributor to fluid volume.
  • Prostate(Option C):Contributes 20-30% of seminal fluid.Secretes acidic fluid with proteolytic enzymes, including PSA, which help liquefy semen.Important, but not the major contributor.
  • Bulbourethral and urethral glands(Option D):Secrete mucus-like fluid before ejaculation (pre-ejaculate).Helps lubricate and neutralize the urethra.Minimal contribution to total semen volume (<5%).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a recognized cause of premature ovarian insufficiency (POI)?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Hormonal therapy (e.g., oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy) does not destroy ovarian follicles or impair long-term ovarian function.
  • Premature Ovarian Insufficiency (POI), also known as premature menopause, refers to the loss of normal ovarian function before the age of 40. It is characterized by:
    • Amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea
    • Elevated FSH levels
    • Low estrogen levels
    • Infertility

Causes of premature ovarian insufficiency (failure)

  • Radiation (pelvic or total body) can damage ovarian follicles, infections such as mumps oophoritis or pelvic infections may destroy ovarian tissue, and oophorectomy (surgical removal of ovaries) causes iatrogenic POI.(Option A,B and C ruled out)
  • Abnormal chromosomal pattern (45XO, 47XXX), causing accelerated follicular atresia
  • Infections (HIV, Mumps, Tuberculosis)
  • Iatrogenic: Radiation, Chemotherapy, Surgery (oophorectomy, excessive ovarian drilling)
  • Metabolic: Galactosemia
  • Autoimmune disorders (Polyglandular autoimmune syndrome).
  • In most of these females pregnancy can be achieved by using donor ovum, however 5-10% of women achieve pregnancy and deliver successfully by their own ova depending on the ovarian reserve. This indicates, women should be assessed for ovarian reserve before planning management.

questions.text: How much of rise in temperature occurs after ovulation
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • After ovulation, a woman's basal body temperature (BBT) rises due to the thermogenic effect of progesterone, which is secreted by the corpus luteum in the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.The temperature typically rises by 0.5°C after ovulation and stays elevated due to progesterone.(Option B,C and D ruled out)

Tests for Documenting Anovulation

questions.text: Most commonly used ovulation induction drug is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • M/C used drug for ovulation Induction is clomiphene citrate
  • Clomiphene Citrate: It is a racemic mixture of enclomiphene and zuclomiphene.Enclomiphene is a more potent isomer responsible for its ovulation-inducing action.
  • Dose = 50-250 mg. However, the US FDA-approved maximum dose for clomiphene citrate is 100 mg
  • Clomiphene blocks "Estrogen" receptors → increase FSH from pituitary →growth of follicles
  • Thus it can be used only in patients with intact hypothalamic -pituitary ovarian axis
  • With clomiphene success rate for ovulation is 80% and success rate for pregnancy is 40%

Explanation of other options:

  • Letrozole(Option A):It is a Aromatase inhibitor → lowers estrogen → increases FSH via negative feedback.Also used for ovulation induction, especially in PCOS patients resistant to clomiphene or as first-line in some guidelines (e.g., ACOG/ESHRE).
  • Gonadotropins(Option C): They are hMG (human menopausal gonadotropins), FSH injections and are used as Second-line in clomiphene-resistant cases or in IVF cycles.
  • Raloxifene(Option D): It is a SERM, but primarily used in osteoporosis treatment.No role in ovulation induction.
